and
split the

in "embooben" (to endow)
identical, use Ambifixation:

in "enchicken"" (to impart the features of a juvenile bird)

member.name: T:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor
member.summary: Enumerates different kinds of affixes.

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Prefix
member.summary: Appears before the stem.

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Suffix
member.summary: Appears after the stem.
member.example:
funny + -ly = funnily
(occuring in a jocular manner)

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Infix
member.summary: Appears inside the stem. Often interchangeable with tmesis.
member.example:
metric ton + fuck = metric fuck-ton
(as differentiated from a long fuck-ton)

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Circumfix
member.summary: Surrounds the stem.
member.example:
boob + em- -en = embooben
(to provide with assets)

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Ambifix
member.summary: Surrounds the stem, where both the preceding and succeding strings are identical.
member.example:
cold + en- -en = encolden
(to approach maximum aloofness)

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Duplifix
member.summary: Duplicates the stem, possibly with ablaution.
member.remarks:
Wikipedia - Duplifix
Not to be confused with " like,
like
like
" (contrastive focus reduplication)
.

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Transfix
member.summary: Alternates between chunks of the stem and root. Supposedly doesn't exist in English; but I bet it does.

member.name: F:FowlFever.Conjugal.Affixing.AffixFlavor.Disfix

member.name: T:FowlFever.Conjugal.Annotations.AbbreviationAttribute
member.summary: Defines an abbreviated form of a's.

member.name: T:FowlFever.Conjugal.Annotations.CollectiveNounAttribute
member.summary: Denotes a term of venery, i.e., the compaynys of beestys and fowlys.
member.example:
From the Book of Saint Albans's the compaynys of beestys and fowlys:
A superfluity of nuns
a feast of brewers
a goring of butchers
an observance of hermits
a school of clerks
a doctrine of doctors
a tabernacle of bakers
a prudence of vicars
a state of princes
a congregation of people
a diligence of messengers
a discretion of priests
an execution of officers
an eloquence of lawyers
a drunkenship of cobblers
a proud showing of tailors
a skulk of thieves
an unkindness of ravens
a clattering of choughs
a murmuration of starlings
a charm of goldfinches
See also:
A Drudge of Lexicographers Presents: Collective Nouns

member.name: T:FowlFever.Conjugal.IConjugal
member.summary: Indicates that this object can be inflected.
member.remarks:
I realize that inflection is is a superset of conjugation and declension, and therefore a more traditionally accurate name would be
IInflective
. I also realize that "conjugatable" is the traditionally correct term, rather than "conjugal". I disagree.
Reasons include:
IInflective would start with two Is.
"Conjugal" sounds much better than "conjugatable".
"Conjugatable" isn't long enough to be fun to say.
"Conjugation" is a superset of both inflection and grammatical conjugation. (This makes conjugation a "set that contains itself," but for some reason I can't find the correct term for that...)
Inflection is jargon; conjugation is a concept.
"Conjugal" is a double entendre.

member.name: P:FowlFever.Conjugal.IConjugal.Lemma

member.name: P:FowlFever.Conjugal.IConjugal.IsProperNoun
